title: Sample Project
text:
One of the interesting projects I worked on was an analysis for the Advanced Spatial Statistics for Urban Applications class. The Pennsylvania legislature advancing a ballot initiative to amend the Constitution of the Commonwealth to prohibit abortion. Knowing that a similar amendment had been made to the Alabama state constitution, I went looking for a multivariable regression model that could explain the outcome. I combined countywide data on religious adherence in 2010 from the Association of Statisticians of American Religious Bodies and the Association of Religion Daily Archives, population demographics, educational attainment, and household data came from the US Census Bureau,  income data came from the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, and annual abortion data released by the Center for Health Statistics of the Alabama Department of Health and compiled by the anti-abortion website (johnstonsarchive.net). I performed the analysis in R. The original analysis included tests for spatial autocorrelation.
The dependent variable measure is (yestotalperc), the percentage of votes cast to amend the constitution. It is not a measure of all eligible voters. Voter turnout in the election was less than 50%. Independent variables incorporated into possible models included the percent of residents who are regular churchgoers (perchurchgo), churchgoers who attend churches affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention, or SBC, (perccgsobap), churchgoers who are not affiliated with the SBC (perccgnonsobap), the average number of abortions for the years 1998 – 2016 by population by county (avgaborperpop), the percentage of black residents by county (percblack), the percentage of households  identifying as female head of household with children – suggesting households run by single-mothers - (percfhhcd), and the percentage of people over 25 with a  bachelor’s degree or higher (college). Income per capita (percapinc) and other variables were also incorporated into trial models.
After exploring correlations in the data, I discovered an interesting relationship between two variables. I had assumed that a yes vote would be correlated with church attendance. The religious data broke down religious observance into different religions and Christian denominations. When I made percent of churchgoers affiliated with the Southern Baptist Convention a separate variable, I was not surprised to see it had a strong positive correlation with yestotalperc. What was surprising was the strong negative correlation with yestotalperc that remained for all other churchgoers. Using ggplot, I made a series of scatterplots to visualize the correlations. The correlations are not clear among churchgoers and non-churchgoers.

I developed several OLS models using different variables. I recorded the various descriptive statistics in the following table.

It became clear that perccgnonsobap and its complement, perccgbsobap, had less explanatory power than percblack. The most powerful 3 variable model I could develop that kept each variable statistically significant was the following multi-variate model consisting of percblack, avgaborperpop, and college. It has an adjusted R-squared of .8541 and an AIC of -206.564.

title: Sample Project
text:
One of the interesting projects I worked on was an analysis for the Advanced Spatial Statistics for Urban Applications class. The Pennsylvania legislature advancing a ballot initiative to amend the Constitution of the Commonwealth to prohibit abortion. I performed the analysis in R. The original analysis included tests for spatial autocorrelation.

plot(cars)
plot(iris)
plot(pressure)















I developed several OLS models using different variables. I recorded the various descriptive statistics in the following table.

It became clear that perccgnonsobap and its complement, perccgbsobap, had less explanatory power than percblack. The most powerful 3 variable model I could develop that kept each variable statistically significant was the following multi-variate This is a span that has the calss aside which places it in the margin without a footnote.
model consisting of percblack, avgaborperpop, and college. It has an adjusted R-squared of .8541 and an AIC of -206.564.

library(ggplot2)
mtcars2 <- mtcars
mtcars2$am <- factor(
  mtcars$am, labels = c('automatic', 'manual')
)
options(options(repr.plot.width = 5, repr.plot.height =2))
ggplot(mtcars2, aes(hp, mpg, color = am)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(formula = y ~ x, method = "loess") +
  theme(legend.position = 'bottom')





Figure 1: MPG vs horsepower, colored by transmission.

I created satellite imagery labels and and trained a machine learning model to classify land use in Baltimore. In this first iteration, the goal was to distinguish between high and medium density residential housing. Check it out

section: Analysis of Atmospheric River Effects in California 2023 Using LANDSAT and Sentinel-1
text:
Analysis of Atmospheric River Effects in California 2023 Using LANDSAT and Sentinel-1


Using NASA datasets from the Google Earth Engine repository, the analysis calculated changes in surface water and saturated soil after severe flooding caused by phenomena dubbed “atmospheric rivers” caused levee breaches, property damage, and left at least 23 people dead. It utilized an open source python module called geemap, a set of python wrappers to facilitate scripts written in jupyter notebooks to be passed back and forth to Earth Engine via the python-api and displayed within the notebook. Calculations included the Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) using LANDSAT imagery and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data from Sentinel-1. Check it out

section: Predicting the Alabama State Constitutional Amendment Vote
text:
Predicting the Alabama State Constitutional Amendment Vote






One of the projects I worked on was an analysis for the Advanced Spatial Statistics for Urban Applications class. The Pennsylvania legislature advancing a ballot initiative to amend the Constitution of the Commonwealth to prohibit abortion. Knowing that a similar amendment had been made to the Alabama state constitution, I went looking for a multivariable regression model that could explain the outcome. I combined statewide county data on religious adherence in 2010 from the Association of Statisticians of American Religious Bodies and the Association of Religion Daily Archives, population demographics, educational attainment, and household data came from the US Census Bureau, income data came from the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, and annual abortion data released by the Center for Health Statistics of the Alabama Department of Health and compiled by the anti-abortion website (johnstonsarchive.net). I performed the analysis in R.Check it out

section: Redistricting Plan Scorer to Compare Compactness, Contiguity, Partisan Fairness, and Population Equality
text:
Redistricting Plan Scorer to Compare Compactness, Contiguity, Partisan Fairness, and Population Equality






Our team built a tool to score proposed congressional redistricting plans on several state legislature and Constitutionally-mandated criteria, including population equality, compactness, and partisan fairness. I coded the GUI in pyQT and was responsible for the partisan fairness tests. - link -

section: Analysis of Atmospheric River Effects in California 2023 Using LANDSAT and Sentinel-1
text:
Analysis of Atmospheric River Effects in California 2023 Using LANDSAT and Sentinel-1


I studied the effects of an “atmospheric river” in early 2023 that left at least 23 people dead in California. The analysis was conducted using python, geemap, and jupyter notebook. Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) using LANDSAT imagery and Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) data from Sentinel-1 were used to calculate standing water left by the event. - link -

section: Machine Learning Land-use Classification in scikit-learn
text:
Machine Learning Land-use Classification in scikit-learn






I created satellite imagery labels and and trained a machine learning model to classify land use in Baltimore. In this first iteration, the goal was to distinguish between high and medium density residential housing. - link -

section: Using Building Renovation Permit Applications as Leading Indicators for Property Crimes
text:
Using Building Renovation Permit Applications as Leading Indicators for Property Crimes


In another analysis, I looked for correlations between the number of building renovation permits filed with the Bureau of Licenses and Inspections and the frequency of reported property crimes in several South Philadelphia neighborhoods. I was interested to see whether permits could be used as a leading indicator. - link -

section: Predicting the Alabama State Constitutional Amendment Vote
text:
Predicting the Alabama State Constitutional Amendment Vote






In another project, I built a multivariable regression model in R to predict the election outcome of a ballot initiative that amended the Alabama State Constitution. - link -

section: Demonstrating K-Means Clustering with Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System and CDC Gun Death Data
text:
Demonstrating K-Means Clustering with Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System and CDC Gun Death Data


As part of a student-led tutorial, I demonstrated the implementation and optimization of K-Means clustering using BRFSS and CDC gun death data. Rates of gun ownership closely correlate with gun deaths.Pictured are 4 clusters of states. An interesting follow-up question is whether the clusters have similar levels of firearm regulation. - link -
